column4: I have a text document lying on the remote server. i have logged in using SSH, and now I want to edit the document. How do I do that?
nano, vim, etc.
But when i write nedit myfile.txt & then I get the message Can't open display
nano, not nedit.  nedit is a GUI
Aha, so I needs to be textbased?
Correct, or you need to do X forwarding
Hmm now i tried nano myFile.txt & but nothing happend
Why did you put the & at the end?
So i can used the terminal

What the & does is means it gets sent to the background.  Whcih means it wont come up so you can see it.  It's running currently (type "jobs") but you may want to look into using screen to give you multiple terminals in one session
when you type "jobs" you'll see the stuff running in the background with a number next to it, type %# where # is the number, to bring that to the foreground
use nano, not vim
Why is Nano better?
nano is more similar to a 'regular' text editor.
vim is VI right?
vim is related to vi, yes.
What is the difference then?
Difference between what?
vim and vi
uh, vim is "vi improved", its got more features, and... specifics are outside the scope of this channel.
Whats wrong with the java in the repos?
The problem is that this is only the runtime environment(JRE). I need the development environment(JDK)
JDK is in the repos too
Is it? But where?
